posts.content:
Looking good Sam, You almost there now?

Seeing the underside picture reminds me to dig out the POR15.

Hope to bump into you soon.

Baz

Yeah, getting there... still plenty to do though I think re-assembly of the van will take about 5 times longer than dis-assembly, if the engine is anything to go by!

Sure to bump into you soon Baz,

Cheers, Sam

More progress to report, we're on welding week 9 (if i haven't lost count, along with my mind and my bank balance) and we're nearly finished! Just a bit more wire-brushing & painting to do underneath to start off with... funny how Dave left me to do the wire-brushing eh...



But managed to make it good...


Meanwhile the major progress has been the doglegs and the front floor... this has been one of those jobs thats dragged on and on because we've been waiting on parts. The original plan was to rip the whole doglegs off and replace with the Gerson panels... these turned out very difficult to get and were a very expensive option ($800 - $1000 for the pair, delivered ). The Brazilian .... ones were not an option - Daves (and Pashs's) experience with them was so bad he refused to work with them and I agreed.

I ended up buying just this panel pair from Autokraft (via Classic Veedub) + the floor panels:


The rest (almost the whole dogleg) was fabricated and repaired by Dave by hand...





view from the inside:


and the front floor:


As a comparison, here's an old pic of what it looked like before. Its difficult to make out but basically the inside dogleg was made up of crap tin panels held in place with gallons of silicon sealant, Yeuch!


Pretty impressive improvement, i think you'll agree.... Amazingly enough, this kind of almost wraps up the welding work for Dave, just a few little odd jobs here and there:


... and I'm turning my thoughts away from the major mechancal work which I've done and onto a few details, like a speedo tidy-up, and those shiny shiny wheels, yay!



So, very soon we're off to the panel shop for some pulling, pushing, pug, paint and polish... I have mixed feelings about this because up until now the work has been very much under our control... from here on in we'll be at the mercy of a paint shop (notoriously unreliable in my experience), so who knows if we'll be 2 months 6 months or 24 months away from cruising around again. SUMMER IS ONLY 3 SHORT MONTHS AWAY AND I DONT WANT TO GO TO THE BEACH IN A TOYOTA WHATEVER!!!!

Cheers, Sam
Oooh, nice update
Excellent dogleg work there, although. seeing as you've lost interest in my resto I might not be back....

moler wrote:
Excellent dogleg work there, although. seeing as you've lost interest in my resto I might not be back....



Moler if you stop taking short-cuts and 'up' the quality a bit, I might take another peek

Thanks for the encouragement...

Just got the engine started





Thanks to Dave (who else?! ) for the loan of the engine starting gubbins... It didn't quite start first time - at first it was just turning over and over - I put a pencil in cylinder no.1 to watch for TDC and the pencil snapped off inside the cylinder!! Eventually got it out with some double-sided tape on the end of a coat-hanger

I'd adjusted all the valves wrong as well.... once that was sorted it fired straight up Da Naaaa

Latest pics... not much welding to report on, Dave is pretty much finished doing his bit so its all down to the panel beater and his bucket of pug from now on in...

Starting bolting stuff back on, which is cool. Here goes the bumpers nicely lined up to weld the bumper brackets on in the right place:



Beam in place...


Yella box...


Side view...


A few more bits to bolt back on then she'll be rolling down to the panel shop - hopefully by this time next week

Kombi now at the panel shop in South Freo... in the lap of the gods now

Here's some pics...

Sam wrote:





Awesome work, credit to all involved - it takes alot of effort to get a your underside looking that good

Look forwards to the next body work update

Progress at the panel-beaters has been slow, unfortunately... two weeks work and all we have to show for it is some bog in the roof:



Still, at least something is happening In the meantime we had noticed that there was a lot of play in the front King Pins, so I took the opportunity to grab the front spindle assemblies off the bus:



Here's what 44 year old king pins look like when they're rooted... i cant imagine these bearing surfaces were doing much good at all, look at all that corrosion and pitting of the top pins:





Curiously, the bottom pins bearing surfaces look very god indeed:



We replaced the whole lot anyway (seeing as I had forked out the AUD$500 for the whole damn lot ), so we pulled the old pins apart (no mean feat), pressed out the old bushes, in with the new and reamed them ready for re-assembly:



And the finished article:



What with the CSP disk brakes, new king pins, link pins, CSP adjusters and EMPI 5's this is going to be one expensive front end, lets hope its worth it and doesn't still wander all over the road

Went to see the van yesterday after a month or so of it being in the panel-beaters. Progress is..... is happening it seems. Much of the paint has been stripped to reveal the horrors (old filler, mainly) underneath, and the process of putting lovely shiny new filler on has started







Some pics of the doors, stripped: Its a testament to the Australian climate that these un-welded original doors are in such good condition, the only repairs needed are to cure accident dings and dents. We had a '73 Bay in the UK which we sprayed ourselves, and the doors were mush!





Bog on, Bog off






Difficult to see, but this panel is still concave and needs some careful pulling out to resolve:



Fingers crossed fr the journey forwards...

Sam

Wow its looking good!
I bet you can't wait till it is finished!

~Lee
